en.title: **Servos**
en.text:
Servo motors are an important part of the InMoov. The robot is made up of servos. All the give the robot its full ability of movement. They come in different sizes and powers and are very useful in our project. When successfully assembled and working, all these servos will provide InMoov with a human-like movement.

**Hacking of servos**
Finally, we will enlarge the hole from where the servo cables come out to allow the potentiometer cables to go through, and we will cut this cables to enlarge their length by adding additional cable in the middle. We also have to bear in mind that for the left arm, and left torso servos we will have potentiometer coming out. to reverse the positive voltage terminal

en.title: **Kinect Sensor**
en.text: The Kinect 360 sensor in the InMoov robot is a motion-sensing input device originally made by Microsoft for the Xbox 360. In the InMoov project, it is repurposed as a vision and tracking system, giving the robot depth perception and environmental awareness.

en.title: **WebCam**
en.text: In the InMoov robot, the webcam plays the crucial role of being the robot's eye. It gives the robot vision, allowing it to see people, objects, and their environment.

en.title: ** NeoPixel**
en.text:
The NeoPixel refers to a popular line of individually addressable RGB LEDs (WS2812B or similar) that include a built-in driver chip. Here is what it does and why it is used in InMoov

In the InMoov robot, Neo Pixels serve primarily decorative and status-indicating functions:Commonly mounted in the stomach area as a colorful ring that lights up to show status (idle, active, tracking) They provide a visual feedback layer, making interactions more engaging.

en.text: he Mini PC speaker (8 Ohm, 10 Watt) is used to give the InMoov robot a voice — allowing it to speak, make sounds, and interact with humans through audio.

en.title: **Arduino mega**
en.text: The Arduino Mega 2560 plays a significant role in the InMoov robot, which is an open-source, 3D-printed humanoid robot developed by Gaël Langevin. The Arduino Mega is often chosen for its substantial number of I/O pins and memory, making it well-suited for complex robotic systems like InMoov.

en.title: **Raspberry Pi 4**
en.text: The Raspberry Pi 4 Model B (8GB) marks a significant milestone in the evolution of single-board computers. With its generous memory capacity, upgraded processing power, and expanded I/O capabilities, this tiny board redefines what is possible in low-cost computing. No longer limited to educational projects and lightweight tasks, the 8GB variant opens the door to high-performance applications such as virtualization, edge computing, media serving, machine learning, and development environments.

en.title: **Nervo boards**
en.text:
the nervo board is a crucial component in the inmoov robot, acting as a bridge between the arduino uno or mega and the servos that power the robot's movements. it's essentially an arduino shield designed to simplify connecting and controlling servos, particularly for the inmoov's hands, head, and other limbs up to 19 servos if used with a arduino mega. 10 sensors connections. 1 pir sensor connection. 1 neopixel ring connection. connection for i2c ready. can be chained through rx/tx.
•the boards is designed and simulated by the aid of ( protues simulator)the board is hardly designed manually using
- copper sheet board
- male pins
-power terminals
-connectors
arduino shield desgin (main board)
•the main board is an extension designed specific for parametres for arduino atmega2650 the main board is supporting the whole functions of the arduino such as the digital pins , analog, pins, power input and output for all pins the main reason for using the board is surface extension of arduino for mounting the whole sub boards also for power distribution for different electronic parts that need various voltage input starting from 3.3~ 6 volts.

ko.title: **Nervo boards**

en.title: **Force Sensitive Resistor Sensor FSR 1.4 **
en.text: Sparkfun force Sensing Resistors (FSR) is a very thin, robust, polymer devices that decrease in resistance when pressure is increased on the surface of the sensor. It is used to sense pressure, weight, contacts and as a touch sensor. These sensors are simple to set up and great for sensing pressure.This FSR will vary its resistance depending on how much pressure is being applied to the sensing area. The harder the force, the lower the resistance. When no pressure is being applied to the FSR its resistance will be larger than 1MΩ. This FSR can sense applied force anywhere in the range of 100g-10kg.Force Sensing Resistors has similar properties to load cell or strain gauge devices. This resistance range is well suited to work directly with the internal pull-ups of many microcontrollers such as AVRs, PICs and arduino.

ko.title: **Force Sensitive Resistor Sensor FSR 1.4 **

en.title: **HC-SR04 Ultrasonic Sensor**
en.text: Tthe HC-SR04 Ultrasonic (US) sensor is a 4 pin module, whose pin names are Vcc, Trigger, Echo and Ground respectively.The sensor works with the simple high school formula thatDistance = Speed × TimeThe Ultrasonic transmitter transmits an ultrasonic wave, this wave travels in air and when it gets objected by any material it gets reflected back toward the sensor this reflected wave is observed

en.title: **PIR**
en.text: sensors are more complicated than many of the other sensors explained in these tutorials (like photocells, FSRs and tilt switches) because there are multiple variables that affect the sensors input and output. To begin explaining how a basic sensor works, we'll use this rather nice diagram The passive infrared (PIR) sensor itself has two slots in it, each slot is made of a special material that is sensitive to IR. The lens used here is not really doing much and so we see that the two slots can 'see' out past some distance (basically the sensitivity of the sensor). When the sensor is idle, both slots detect the same amount of IR, the ambient amount radiated from the room or walls or outdoors. When a warm body like a human or animal passes by, it first intercepts one half of the PIR sensor, which causes a positive differential change between the two halves. When the warm body leaves the sensing area, the reverse happens, whereby the sensor generates a negative differential change.
